Description: Fragment of a mould-made figurine representing a mammal, a jackal, a dog, a donkey or a horse; long slightly pointed nose with two nostrils marked by small depressions, well modelled eyes and straight pointed ears (one is missing); amuletic function very uncertain; light turquoise glaze; cream core; only head survives.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For jackal's head as amulet, a New Kingdom example is illustrated in Andrews 1994, fig. 70c. It is however not a close parallel. This piece could be part of a toy. Andrews, C. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.273) (phase 3)
